title: Understanding Cervical Cancer
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value:
Cervical cancer is a cancer that begins in the **cervix**, the lower part of the uterus that connects to the vagina. It is strongly linked to persistent infection with **high-risk types of HPV** (Human Papillomavirus).

Because of screening programs, cervical cancer is often detected early — sometimes even before cancer develops.

content.description: Nearly all cervical cancers are caused by HPV infection.

content.value: Cervical cancer usually begins with pre-cancerous changes in the cells of the cervix called **CIN (Cervical Intraepithelial Neoplasia)**. If untreated, some CIN lesions may slowly progress to cancer over many years.

items.title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma
items.description: The most common type — 70–80% of cervical cancers. Starts in the thin, flat cells on the outer surface of the cervix.

items.title: Adenocarcinoma
items.description: Begins in the glandular cells inside the cervical canal. Less common but often harder to detect through routine screening.

items.title: Rare Types
items.description: Includes small cell neuroendocrine carcinoma and other mixed tumours. These are uncommon but tend to behave more aggressively.

content.title: Did You Know?
content.description: CIN does not always turn into cancer. Regular screening and early treatment of abnormal cells can stop cervical cancer before it starts.

content.value: Major factors that increase the risk of cervical cancer.

items.title: Persistent High-Risk HPV Infection
items.content: The strongest risk factor. Nearly all cervical cancers are linked to high-risk HPV types.

items.title: Smoking
items.content: Smoking reduces the body's ability to clear HPV infections, increasing cancer risk.

items.title: Weakened Immune System
items.content: Conditions like HIV or long-term steroid use weaken immunity and raise risk.

items.title: Sexual Activity at a Young Age
items.content: Early sexual activity increases the chance of HPV exposure.

items.title: Multiple Sexual Partners
items.content: More partners increase the likelihood of high-risk HPV infection.

items.title: Long-Term Oral Contraceptive Use
items.content: Using the contraceptive pill for more than 5 years slightly increases risk.

items.title: Lack of Cervical Screening
items.content: Skipping Pap smears or HPV tests means abnormalities can go undetected.

items.title: Other STIs (e.g., Chlamydia)
items.content: Certain infections make HPV more persistent, raising risk.

items.title: Family History of Cervical Cancer
items.content: Risk is slightly higher if a close relative has had cervical cancer.

content.title: Most Important Risk Factor
content.description: HPV is the most important risk factor — nearly all cervical cancers are HPV-related.

content.value: Cervical cancer often develops without early warning signs. That's why regular screenings are essential.

items.title: Pelvic pain
items.description: Persistent pain in the pelvic area

items.title: Pain or bleeding during or after sex
Unusual vaginal discharge
items.description: Changes in discharge color or smell

items.title: Bleeding after menopause
items.description: Any bleeding after menopause should be checked

content.title: Important
content.description: If you notice any of these symptoms, contact your doctor promptly.

content.value: If a Pap test shows abnormal results, your doctor may recommend further tests to confirm abnormalities.

content.title: Thorough Evaluation
content.description: A combination of tests helps ensure accurate diagnosis

steps: Repeat Pap Smear or Liquid-Based Cytology
Colposcopy — a magnifying instrument to examine the cervix
Biopsy — tissue sample examined under microscope
Endo-Cervical Curettage — tissue from cervical canal
Cone Biopsy — larger tissue sample if needed

content.value: If doctors suspect the cancer has spread, they may recommend:
Treatment depends on the type, stage, and spread of the cancer — as well as your overall health and personal needs.

items.title: Surgery (Often the First Step)
items.content: Cryosurgery, Cone biopsy, LEEP (Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure), Hysterectomy, or Total pelvic exenteration for advanced cases.

items.title: Radiation Therapy
items.content: High-energy rays to destroy cancer cells. May be external beam or internal (brachytherapy).

items.title: Chemotherapy
items.content: Drugs that kill or slow the growth of cancer cells. Often combined with radiation.

items.title: Targeted or Immunotherapy
items.content: Used in select cases to boost treatment effectiveness, especially for recurrent cancer.

content.title: Recovery & Support
content.description: Enhanced recovery programs and multi-specialty teams work together to design the best care plan for you.

content.value: Cervical cancer is one of the most preventable cancers.

items.text: Regular cervical screening (Pap smear / HPV testing)
Prompt treatment of CIN or HPV-related changes

content.value: The most important points to remember about cervical cancer.

items.text: HPV is the main cause of cervical cancer
Screening can detect pre-cancer before symptoms appear
Early stages often have no symptoms
Regular check-ups and prompt follow-ups save lives

content.value: **Don't wait for symptoms — regular screening saves lives.**
